currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences.

 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelle

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause t

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growin

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.

That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us moni

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. Q

 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm pr

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am bet

 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phon

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain numbe

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hour

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or d

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I fi

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping

That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.

 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone, but if w

That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone, but if we can find any bright

 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone, but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will fi

 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will find them in retrospe

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will find them in retrospect. We are living through a difficult time, but it will help

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will find them in retrospect. We are living through a difficult time, but it will help us to learn how to live better. Screen

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will find them in retrospect. We are living through a difficult time, but it will help us to learn how to live better. Screen time is something that we will always grapple with, now

For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will find them in retrospect. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will find them in retrospect. We are living through a difficult time, but it will help us to learn how to live better. Screen time is something that we will always grapple with, but through this experience we will find ways to use

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time is an important benchmark in how we are spending our time. Whether or not there is inherent risk in what we do on our screens aside, spending too much time staring at a screen is physically unhealthy. t's not just the eyes that suffer, it's the body.
 Physical exercise is important for people to maintain energy. When we sit, lay or even stand in one position for too long, our bodies suffer the consequences. 
I'm not saying that we should all go out and run a marathon.
 What I'm saying is that we need to be mindful of how much time we spend in a stationary position. The pandemic has accelerated our submersion into a more digital world. That is unfortunate, but it didn't cause this particular problem but rather just shined a light on an already growing issue that people were facing, especially children and young people.  
The good news is that we can all take steps to mitigate the negative effects of screen time.
 Apps are available for all major platforms which can help us monitor our screen time. I use Moment on my iPhone and it's a great way to keep track of how much time I spend on my phone. With the information I'm provided, by the app, I am better able to manage my daily activities. For instance, I can restrict my phone usage to a certain number of minutes, or hours, before taking a break to exercise, rest or do something else. I find that when I'm keeping track of my time in a more detailed way, I am shocked by the amount of time I devote to staring at a screen.  also use a desktop app called Self Control to block certain websites for a set amount of time.


The pandemic is very difficult for everyone but if we can find any bright spots in the tragedy of this time period, I think we will find them in retrospect. We are living through a difficult time, but it will help us to learn how to live better. Screen time is something that we will always grapple with, but through this experience we will find ways to use our devices more s
